question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined words in the given sentence.
Rare species o̲f̲ ̲f̲r̲o̲g̲s̲ ̲w̲e̲r̲e̲ ̲v̲e̲r̲y̲ ̲q̲u̲i̲c̲k̲e̲r̲ identified by Stella.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 10-Sep Shift 2)
option_1: to frogs were very quickly
option_2: of frogs were very quickly
option_3: in frogs were very quicker
option_4: of frogs were very quicklier
solution:
Correct Answer: of frogs were very quickly
Explanation: The correct phrasing is "Rare species of frogs were very quickly identified by Stella," where "of frogs" is the proper possessive form and "very quickly" is the appropriate adverbial form describing how the species were identified

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined word in the given sentence.
Pollution levels have increased so l̲a̲r̲g̲e̲l̲y̲ that they are almost killing us.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 09-Sep Shift 2)
solution:
Correct Answer:highly

Explanation: The word "largely" in the sentence means to a great extent or degree. The most appropriate synonym here is "highly", which also indicates a great degree or extent, especially in terms of intensity.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined words in the given sentence.
Ice m̲e̲l̲t̲s̲ ̲f̲a̲s̲t̲l̲y̲,̲in the sun.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 29 June Shift-3)
solution:
The most appropriate substitution for the underlined words is:

melts fast

This option correctly uses the adverb "fast" to modify the verb "melts," which is the proper form. "Fastly" is not a standard adverb in English, and the other options don't fit grammatically:

  • melts fastest would be incorrect because it implies a comparison, which is not intended here.

  • melt fast is incorrect because it doesn't match the singular subject "ice."

  • melt fastly is grammatically incorrect, as "fastly" is not a standard word.

So, melts fast is the correct choice.

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed, select ‘No improvement required’.
She r̲u̲n̲s̲ ̲m̲o̲r̲e̲ ̲f̲a̲s̲t̲e̲r̲ ̲t̲h̲a̲n̲ her brother in the track events.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (8 Mar))
solution:
The underlined phrase "runs more faster than" is grammatically incorrect because it uses a double comparative — both "more" and "faster" indicate comparison, which is unnecessary.

  • The correct comparative form of "fast" is "faster", not "more fast" or "more faster".

  • Hence, "runs faster than" is the correct and concise form.

Correct sentence:
She runs faster than her brother in the track events.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence to improve it. If no improvement is required, select ‘No improvement required’.
Effective communication is a skill t̲h̲a̲t̲ ̲c̲a̲n̲ ̲s̲i̲g̲n̲i̲f̲i̲c̲a̲n̲t̲ ̲e̲n̲h̲a̲n̲c̲e̲ your personal and professional life.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-2)
solution:
Solution:
The original sentence:
"Effective communication is a skill that can significant enhance your personal and professional life."
contains an error in the adverb usage. "Significant" (adjective) should be replaced with the adverb "significantly" to correctly modify the verb "enhance".

Correct version: "that can significantly enhance..."
Also, the use of "which" in place of "that" is grammatically acceptable in this context, though "that" is fine too.

Option A: "which can significant enhanced" – ❌ incorrect tense and word form
Option B: "which can significantly enhancing" – ❌ ungrammatical structure
Option C: "No improvement required" – ❌ incorrect because of "significant"
Option D: ✔ correct word choice and structure

Answer: Option D (which can significantly enhance).

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed, select ‘No improvement required’.
H̲e̲ ̲s̲p̲e̲a̲k̲s̲ ̲E̲n̲g̲l̲i̲s̲h̲ ̲g̲o̲o̲d̲ ̲e̲n̲o̲u̲g̲h̲ to communicate with foreign clients.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (30 April))
option_2: He is speaking English good enough
option_3: He speaks English better enough
option_4: He speaks English well enough
solution:
Explanation:

  • The word “good” is an adjective. However, here we need an adverb to modify the verb “speaks”.

  • The correct adverb form of "good" is “well.”

  • So, the correct phrase is: “He speaks English well enough…”

Revised sentence:
He speaks English well enough to communicate with foreign clients.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
He is a̲l̲m̲o̲s̲t̲ ̲q̲u̲i̲e̲t̲ well.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (04-July Shift 3))
solution:
Solution:
In the sentence, "quite" is the correct adverb to modify the adjective "well" (which here means ‘good’ or ‘fine’). The phrase "quite well" means "fairly well" or "to a considerable extent well."

  • almost quietly (option 1) is incorrect because quietly is an adverb of manner and doesn't fit well with well here.

  • very quite (option 2) is grammatically incorrect as very should not directly modify quite.

  • quiet (option 4) is an adjective, and cannot modify well which requires an adverb.

Part of Speech Details:

  • quite is an adverb modifying the adjective well.

Hence, the correct phrase is "He is quite well." (Option 3)

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
He ̲t̲a̲k̲e̲s̲ ̲h̲i̲s̲ ̲a̲l̲w̲a̲y̲s̲ ̲d̲o̲g̲ ̲f̲o̲r̲ ̲a̲ ̲w̲a̲l̲k̲ ̲in the park.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (04-July Shift 4))
option_1: his dog for a walk always takes
option_2: always takes his dog for a walk
option_3: takes his dog for always a walk
option_4: takes his dog for an always walk
solution:
Correct Answer:always takes his dog for a walk

Explanation:

The sentence is:
He takes his always dog for a walk in the park.
This is grammatically incorrect because the adverb "always" is placed awkwardly between "his" and "dog."

Let’s evaluate the options:

  • his dog for a walk always takes – incorrect word order; awkward and ungrammatical.

  • always takes his dog for a walk – ✅ grammatically correct and natural word order.

  • takes his dog for always a walk – incorrect placement of "always."

  • takes his dog for an always walk – incorrect because "always" cannot modify "walk" in this way.

✅ “Always takes his dog for a walk” is the correct substitution, with "always" placed properly as an adverb modifying the verb "takes."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Sarita speaks French b̲e̲s̲t̲.̲

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (08-July Shift 1))
solution:
Correct Answer:well

Explanation:

The original sentence is:
Sarita speaks French best.

Let’s understand why "best" may be inappropriate here:

  • “Best” is the superlative form of the adverb "well", used when comparing more than two options (e.g., She speaks French best among her friends).

  • However, in this sentence, there is no comparison being made.

  • If we're simply stating how Sarita speaks French (without comparing), the correct adverb is "well".

So, the corrected sentence is:
✅ Sarita speaks French well.

Part of speech corrected:Adverb — changed from superlative (best) to positive form (well) to match the sentence context.

question:
Select the option that rectifies the given sentence.
She runs very quick in marathons.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.16_14-Oct_Shift-2)
option_1: She run very quick in marathons.
option_2: She runs very quickly in marathons.
option_3: She run much quickly in marathons.
option_4: She runs much quickly in marathons.
solution:
Correct Answer: She runs very quickly in marathons.

Explanation:

  • The word "quick" is an adjective, but in this sentence, we need an adverb to modify the verb "runs".

  • ✅ The correct adverb form is "quickly".

  • The verb "runs" is also correctly used in present simple tense with "she" as the subject.

Let’s eliminate the other options:

  • She run – incorrect; verb should be "runs" with "she".

  • Much quickly – incorrect usage; "very quickly" is more natural and grammatically appropriate in this context.

Therefore, the corrected sentence is: "She runs very quickly in marathons."

question:
Correct the underlined part of the sentence.
The rabbit runs f̲a̲s̲t̲l̲y̲.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.24_17-Oct_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: fast

Explanation:
The word "fastly" is incorrect because "fast" is an adverb that does not change form.

Correct usage:

  • The rabbit runs fast.

  • For comparisons: faster, fastest

  • For equality: as fast as

Other options:

  • fastest – superlative form, used when comparing more than two

  • as fast as – used in comparisons of equality

  • faster – comparative form, used when comparing two things

Since the sentence is a simple statement, the correct word is "fast."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution required’.
Her team played exceptionally m̲o̲r̲e̲ ̲w̲e̲l̲l̲ in the competition.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.53_05-Nov_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: well

Explanation:
The phrase "more well" is incorrect because "well" is an irregular adverb whose comparative form is "better", not "more well."

In the sentence, "exceptionally well" correctly expresses a high degree of skill or performance.

Correct sentence:
"Her team played exceptionally well in the competition."

So, the word "well" should replace "more well" to make the sentence grammatically correct and natural.

question:
Select the grammatically INCORRECT sentence.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (11-July Shift 4))
option_1: They hardly meet each other.
option_2: They often meet each other.
option_3: They quite meet each other.
option_4: They always meet each other.
solution:
Correct Answer: They quite meet each other.

Explanation:
The adverb "quite" is not used with the verb "meet" in this way. It needs to be followed by an adjective or used differently (e.g., "They are quite close").

The other sentences are grammatically correct:

  • They hardly meet each other.

  • They often meet each other.

  • They always meet each other.

So, the incorrect sentence is:
"They quite meet each other."

question:
Select the sentence with the appropriate use of adverb of manner.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 1 Dec Shift-1)
option_1: He has just done his work.
option_2: He done his work regularly.
option_3: He has done his work on my table.
option_4: He does his work carefully.
solution:
Correct Answer:He does his work carefully.

Explanation:
An adverb of manner explains how an action is performed (कोई कार्य कैसे किया जाता है).
The sentence "He does his work carefully" correctly uses carefully as an adverb of manner, meaning with attention or caution (सावधानी से).

Other options do not have adverbs of manner:

  • just in "He has just done his work" is an adverb of time (अभी-अभी).

  • regularly in "He done his work regularly" is an adverb of frequency (नियमित रूप से).

  • on my table in "He has done his work on my table" is an adverbial phrase of place (मेरी मेज़ पर).

Thus, the correct sentence using an adverb of manner is:
"He does his work carefully."

question:
Select the appropriate option to replace the underlined word with the adverb of time.
I went to Paris r̲e̲g̲u̲l̲a̲r̲l̲y̲.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 1 Dec Shift-3)
solution:
Correct Answer:yesterday

Explanation:
The underlined word "regularly" is an adverb of frequency, which tells us how often something happens (नियमित रूप से).

The question asks for a replacement with an adverb of time, which tells us when something happened (कब हुआ).

Let’s evaluate the options:

  • often – adverb of frequency (कई बार/अक्सर) ❌

  • twice – adverb of frequency (दो बार) ❌

  • happily – adverb of manner (कैसे किया – खुशी से) ❌

  • yesterday – ✅ adverb of time (कल), which tells when the action happened

✅ So, the correct sentence becomes:
"I went to Paris yesterday."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
I am sure you can win the match i̲f̲ ̲y̲o̲u̲ ̲t̲r̲y̲ ̲h̲a̲r̲d̲l̲y̲.̲

(SSC CPO 2022 T-1 : 10 Nov Shift-2)
option_2: if you are trying hardly
option_3: if you will try hardly
solution:
Answer: 4 – if you try hard

Solution (Correct Option – 4: if you try hard):
The correct phrase is "try hard", which means to make a strong effort.
The original sentence says:
"I am sure you can win the match if you try hard."
This is grammatically and idiomatically correct.

Why the original segment is incorrect:
The original uses "try hardly", which is wrong because "hardly" means 'barely' or 'almost not', so "try hardly" would mean to barely try, which is the opposite of what's intended.

Why other options are incorrect:
Option 1: if you trying hard – Incorrect structure; “trying” needs an auxiliary verb like “are”.
Option 2: if you are trying hardly – Again misuses "hardly" (means barely), and the tense is awkward.
Option 3: if you will try hardly – "Will try" is future tense, and "hardly" again means barely, which doesn't fit. Also, "if" clauses with "will" are incorrect in such conditional sentences.

Difficult Word Meanings:
Hard – with a lot of effort (कड़ी मेहनत से)
Hardly – scarcely, almost not (मुश्किल से / शायद ही)

question:
Select the appropriate adverb for the underlined word in the sentence.
I c̲o̲m̲p̲l̲e̲t̲e̲ forgot her birthday, and I don’t know how to make it up to her.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 13 Dec Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: completely

Explanation:

  • The word forgot is a verb, and we need an adverb to modify it.

  • Completely is the correct adverb form of complete, and it describes the extent to which something was forgotten (पूरी तरह भूल गया).

Other options:

  • Completeness – a noun (पूर्णता) ❌

  • Completed – a verb/adjective (पूरा किया हुआ) ❌

  • Completing – present participle/gerund ❌

Correct sentence:
I completely forgot her birthday, and I don’t know how to make it up to her.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution required’.
You c̲a̲n̲ ̲f̲o̲l̲l̲o̲w̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲i̲n̲s̲t̲r̲u̲c̲t̲i̲o̲n̲s̲ ̲f̲a̲i̲t̲h̲f̲u̲l̲, to avoid being disqualified.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 18 Nov S-2)
option_1: should follow the instructions faithfully
option_3: shall be followed by the instructions faithfully
option_4: cannot follow the instructions faithfully
solution:
Correct Answer: should follow the instructions faithfully
Explanation:
 The original sentence – “You can follow the instructions faithful…” is incorrect because "faithful" is an adjective, while an adverb is needed to modify the verb "follow".
 The correct adverb form is "faithfully" (ईमानदारी से / निष्ठा से).
 Also, "should" is more appropriate than "can" in this context, as the sentence gives advice or a recommendation to avoid disqualification.

Correct sentence: You should follow the instructions faithfully to avoid being disqualified.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution required’.
Sara will go to the seminar first and l̲a̲t̲e̲r̲ attend class.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 18 Nov S-3)
solution:
Answer:No substitution required

Explanation:

  • The phrase "Sara will go to the seminar first and later attend class." is grammatically and contextually correct.


  • 🟢 "Later" is used here as an adverb meaning "afterward" or "after the first event" (बाद में), which fits perfectly.

Other options:

  1. ❌ "Latter" – refers to the second of two mentioned items, not about time.

  2. ❌ "Late" – means not on time (देरी से), which changes the meaning.

  3. ❌ "Letter" – unrelated noun (पत्र), incorrect in context.

✅ Therefore, the sentence needs no change.
Correct sentence: "Sara will go to the seminar first and later attend class."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution required’.
The dress m̲a̲y̲ ̲p̲l̲e̲a̲s̲a̲n̲t̲l̲y̲ be delivered to us at the earliest.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 19 Apr S2 (12_30 to 1_30 PM))
solution:
Explanation:

Correct Answer: may kindly

🔍 What’s the grammatical issue?

  • Error Type: Incorrect adverb choice / Politeness in formal request

  • Part of speech affected:Adverb modifying modal verb + passive verb

📘 Grammar Rule Involved:

In formal English, especially in official or polite requests, the word “kindly” is used instead of “pleasantly” when you're asking for something to be done in a courteous way.

  • ❌ "May pleasantly be delivered"

  • Pleasantly (आनंदपूर्वक) describes mood or manner, not appropriateness for a polite request.

  • Sounds unnatural in this context.

  • ✅ "May kindly be delivered"

  • Kindly (कृपया) is the correct formal adverb used in passive voice requests.

🧠 Think of this standard structure:

“The documents may kindly be sent to the undersigned.”
NOT
“The documents may pleasantly be sent...”

❌ Evaluation of Other Options:

  • must pleasantly

  • ❌ Must is too forceful (अनिवार्यता दिखाता है), and pleasantly is still inappropriate here.

  • Incorrect tone and word choice.

  • might kindly

  • ⚠ Might is more tentative than may, and not commonly used in such passive polite constructions.

  • Slightly awkward but not grammatically wrong — just less formal than “may kindly.”

  • No substitution required

  • ❌ Pleasantly is not suitable — error exists. Substitution is required.

🟢 So, the correct option is: may kindly,

because it correctly expresses a formal, polite passive request, replacing the misused adverb "pleasantly".

question:
Select the appropriate adverb for the underlined word in the sentence.
He led me to the room that had o̲b̲v̲i̲o̲u̲s̲ been built later than the rest of the house.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 2 Dec Shift-1)
solution:
Correct Answer:obviously

Explanation:
In the sentence:
"He led me to the room that had o̲b̲v̲i̲o̲u̲s̲ been built later than the rest of the house."
The underlined word "obvious" is incorrect because we need an adverb to modify the verb "had been built" — describing how it had been built (i.e., in a way that is clear or evident).

  • obviously is the correct adverb form of obvious, meaning clearly or evidently (स्पष्ट रूप से).

  • oblivously ❌ – not a correct word.

  • obviousness ❌ – a noun (स्पष्टता), not an adverb.

  • obliviousness ❌ – a noun meaning lack of awareness (अनभिज्ञता), unrelated to the context.

Corrected sentence:
"He led me to the room that had obviously been built later than the rest of the house."

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If no substitution is required, select ‘No substitution’.
Many artisans were a̲l̲m̲o̲s̲t̲ ̲w̲i̲t̲h̲o̲u̲t̲ ̲a̲n̲y̲ work during the pandemic.

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 23 August Shift 3 (3 to 4 PM))
solution:
Answer: No substitution
Solution:
• The sentence "Many artisans were almost without any work during the pandemic" is grammatically correct and natural in meaning.
• The phrase "almost without any work" means they had very little or nearly no work, which is appropriate in this context.
• The word order and structure follow standard English usage.

Why the other options are incorrect:
• without any almost – incorrect word order; sounds awkward and ungrammatical.
• any without almost – jumbled structure; grammatically wrong.
• almost any without – illogical and meaningless in this context.

question:
Select the sentence with the appropriate use of adverb of frequency.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 3 Dec Shift-2)
option_1: Radha goes to Nagpur to meet her uncle.
option_2: Radha often goes to Nagpur.
option_3: Radha goes to Nagpur with great affection.
option_4: Radha goes to Nagpur for her office work.
solution:
Answer: Radha often goes to Nagpur.

Explanation:
The word often is an adverb of frequency, indicating how frequently Radha makes the trip. The other sentences either lack a frequency adverb or use different types of modifiers.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
A̲t̲ ̲s̲o̲m̲e̲ ̲p̲o̲i̲n̲t̲ ̲i̲n̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲p̲a̲s̲t̲,̲ there were rows of temporary shops that used to display various cooking utensils.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 4 Oct Shift-3 (4 to 6 PM))
option_3: In the past few years
solution:
The most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment "At some point in the past" in the given sentence would be: Long ago
Explanation:

"Long ago" suggests a distant past, indicating that the situation described occurred a significant amount of time before the present. It effectively conveys the idea of temporal distance and aligns with the context of the sentence, which discusses a past occurrence that is not specific to any recent time frame. Therefore, "Long ago" is the most suitable option to maintain the intended meaning of the sentence.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Malati has a difficult job, but she does it g̲o̲o̲d̲.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 4 Oct Shift-3 (4 to 6 PM))
solution:
The most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment "good" in the given sentence is: "well"
"Well" is the adverb form of "good" and is used to describe how an action is performed. In this context, it accurately reflects Malati's performance in her difficult job. Using "well" indicates that Malati does her job skillfully or effectively.

question:
Select the appropriate option to replace the underlined word with the adverb of frequency.
He d̲i̲d̲ ̲n̲o̲t̲ ̲a̲d̲m̲i̲t̲ that his team played badly.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 6 Dec Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: never admitted

Explanation:

  • Never is an adverb of frequency (आवृत्ति का क्रिया विशेषण) that means at no time or not ever (कभी नहीं).

  • The sentence becomes: “He never admitted that his team played badly.”

  • The other options do not express frequency:

  • happily admitted – adverb of manner (खुशी से)

  • yesterday admitted – adverb of time (कल)

  • willingly admitted – adverb of manner (स्वेच्छा से)

question:
Select the appropriate adverb for the underlined word in the sentence.
We considered i̲n̲ ̲b̲r̲i̲e̲f̲ the long term solution to the problem.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 8 Dec Shift-4)
solution:
Answer: briefly

Explanation:
“Briefly” is the adverb form meaning in a concise manner (संक्षेप में). It correctly replaces “in brief” to modify the verb “considered.”

  • brief is an adjective, not an adverb

  • briefness is a noun, and briefless is not a valid form

Thus, briefly fits the grammatical requirement.
